security: Disclosing details of communication with opposition leaders in South Vietnam regarding potential coups could jeopardize relationships with current government officials and reveal intelligence-gathering methods. Specific mention of 'certain general officers have consulted with him on the possibility of attempting a coup d'etat' and discussions around 'the method to be employed and the consequences to LY' highlights these sensitivities.
summary: A CIA information report details comments from opposition leader Tran Van Ly regarding the potential for a coup d'etat in South Vietnam, including his concerns about methods and consequences.
summary_one_paragraph: This January 28, 1962, CIA telegram reports on comments made by Tran Van Ly, an opposition leader in South Vietnam, regarding the possibility of a coup d'etat. Ly, who was previously imprisoned following the attempted coup of 1960, indicated that certain generals consulted him about a potential coup to prevent the country from falling to Vietnamese Communists. While agreeing in principle, Ly expressed concern over the methods and consequences, emphasizing the need to avoid bloodshed and minimize the force used to prevent exploitation by the Viet Cong. Ly suggested declaring a state of siege, controlling troop movements, and forming a Revolutionary Committee with technical advisors to manage the government temporarily, allowing the people to choose a head of state.
title: Information Report Re: Comments
